The women of the Corépa 2 Group in Palmarin ecovillage (http://www.sem-fund.org/palmarinfr.php) would like to thank Kiva for having faith in them. They are, however, calling on Kiva again to request a new loan of 700,000 F ($1,500) to allow them to keep their dyeing businesses going. With this loan, they will buy dyeing materials and lots of fabric to increase their stock. They will use this fabric to make clothes that will be sold in tourist outlets in the ecovillage and also sent off to Dakar, the capital of Senegal, for a fast sale.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabrics to dye and sell

loans.name: Estrellas Brillante Group

texts.en:
This is a group of five women trying to receive loans to increase their businesses. The name of their group is "Estrellas Brillante". Each one of these members has received loans before, and all of them were very diligent in paying back their loans.

Alicia is the representative of this group, and has proven to be a very hardworking woman. She said she has to work hard because she has four young children that she needs to take care of and feed. She has a small business selling food in her area. She hopes to have her own restaurant someday, and move out of the area she is in. She said it's a goal to put all her kids through high school, and hopefully they will be able to go to college someday. She is ready to start changing her life and the life of her children!

On behalf of Alicia, the group, and Esperanza International - Thank you for your help!!!

loans.use: To buy products for making food

loans.name: Valentin Felix

texts.es:
Valentin es artesano y confecciona sombreros para el sol, los comercializa por docena a los puestos de venta donde venden por detalle; también comercializa en el interior (Santa Cruz y Cochabamba). Esta actividad es su fuente de ingreso con  que cubre la manutención de su pequeño hijo y su madre. Valentín vive en la casa de su hermana ubicado en la Zona 16 de febrero – Rio Seco de la ciudad de El Alto.
 
El préstamo lo destinará para la compra de materia prima (tela) con que podrá satisfacer la cantidad de demanda que tiene en su mercado.
 
Es primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada califica favorablemente la aprobación del préstamo solicitado.
texts.en:
Valentin is a craftsman and makes sun hats, which he sells by the dozen at retail stalls; he also sells inland (Santa Cruz and Cochabamba). This trade is the source of income with which he keeps his young son and mother. Valentin lives at his sister’s house in the 16 de febrero area of Rio Seco, in the city of El Alto.

He will use the loan to buy raw materials (fabric) with which he can meet market demand.

He has been approved by evaluation to receive his first requested loan with Impro.

Translated from Spanish by Eleanor Stilgoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: RAW MATERIALS (FABRIC)

loans.name: Liliana

texts.es:
Liliana V. G. forma parte del Banco Comunal “Manuela Ramos de Tinco” de la provincia de Carhuaz.

Liliana tiene 37 años de edad es madre soltera de 02 hijos, ella es profesora, y  siendo su profesión el mas grande logro en su vida personal, Liliana alterna su trabajo de profesora con la actividad de crianza y comercialización de cerdos, animal que compra en la feria de Carhuaz o de la zona rural del distrito de Tinco y lo vende a pedido en su casa o lleva la carne directamente hasta los compradores. Liliana afirma que ha crecido regularmente porque cuando inició su negocio lo hizo con una inversión de s/300.00 y en la actualidad ella invierte más de s/1000.00 en cada compra, aunque comenta que en la última compra que realizó, la carne de uno de los cerdos tenía triquina (parásito que se aloja en la carne de cerdo, totalmente dañino para la salud humana), problema común en este negocio afirma Liliana, razón por la cual ahora también comercializará cuyes para diversificar sus productos y seguir creciendo en su negocio.
  
Con este préstamo de s/.2,500.00, que pagará en ocho cuotas invertirá en la compra de cuyes y cerdos.
 
Liliana asume que es necesario aprender de nuevas alternativas de negocio para seguir creciendo.
texts.en:
Liliana V. G. is part of the communal bank “Manuela Ramos de Tinco” in the Carhuaz province. Liliana is 37 years old and the single mother of 2 sons. She is a teacher and considers her profession the greatest achievement of her personal life. Liliana alternates her work as a teacher with work growing and selling pigs. She buys the animals at the Carhuaz fair or in the rural zone of the Tinco district and then sells them to order from her home, or delivers the meat directly to her clients. Liliana asserts that her business has grown steadily. When she started the business she did so with an investment of 300 Peruvian soles and currently she invests more than 1000 soles into every animal purchase. However, she add that one of the pigs she bought in her last purchase was infested with trichina (a parasite that lives in pork meat and is a threat to human health); trichina is a common problem in Liliana's line of business. For that reason she will now also market guinea pigs in order to diversify her products and continue growing her business. With this loan of 2,500 soles, which she will repay in 8 installements, Lillian will invest in the purchase of guinea pigs and swine. Liliana takes as a given the need to learn about new lines of business in order to continue growing.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy young animals (guinea pigs and swine)

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
La señora Yolanda es socia del Banco Comunal “Sacuyo”, proviene del sector Asunción, en la comunidad de Sacuyo, distrito de Acora, Provincia de Puno, Departamento de Puno; tiene 25 años de edad, es conviviente y tiene dos hijos, posee estudios de primaria completa.
Trabaja desde hace un año con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos, posee un negocio de elaboración y acopio de quesos para venta en los mercado locales de Puno; su primer préstamo fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, monto que destino para comprar algunos materiales (moldes, cuajo, prensas) y acopiar mas quesos para comercializarlos.
Actualmente ella desea un capital adicional para mejorar su producción de quesos, y viene solicitando un nuevo préstamo de S/. 1000.00 Nuevos soles, asimismo ella solicita capacitaciones para poder elaborar quesos de diferentes tipos y que aguanten mas en los mercados, las ganancias las invertirá en adquirir mas ganado vacuno e instalar pastos cultivados para producir mas leche ello, agradece a Manuela Ramos por su apoyo, ya que le permitió mejorar la calidad de vida en su hogar y una ayuda a la educación de sus hijos, finalmente se compromete a pagar puntualmente su préstamo en tres cuotas mensuales.
texts.en:
Señora Yolanda is a member of the community bank “Sacuyo”. She is from Asunción, in the community of Sacuyo in the Acora District, Province of Puno, Department of Puno. She is 25 years old, has a common-law spouse and two children. She studied through primary school. For the past year she has worked with the Manuela Ramos movement. She has a business of making and curing of cheese for sale in the local markets in Puno. Her first loan was of S/.500.00 Nuevos Soles. She used it to buy various materials (molds, rennant, presses) and to cure more cheeses to sell them. Currently she would like some additional capital in order to improve her cheese production, and so she is asking for a new loan of S/.1000.00 Nuevos Soles. With this loan she is asking for, she will gain capacity to make different types of cheese and to take more to the markets. The income would be invested to acquire more cattle and to plant a pasture in order to produce more milk, she thanks Manuela Ramos for the help that has already permitted her to improve the quality of life in her home and to help with the education of her children. Finally, she promises to pay punctually her loan in three monthly installments.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To get more livestock and grow pasture to produce more milk

loans.name: Rosalino

texts.es: Rosalino tiene 34 años, vive hace 5 años con su pareja con la que tiene tres hijos, actualmente viven en su casa propia. Él y su esposa se han propuesto sembrar chacras de café y plantas de diversas frutas, en algunos casos espera 3 largos años para la cosecha, en otros es cada 15 días, por ello está muy contento porque esta actividad le permite cubrir la alimentación y el bienestar de su familia, además le llena de alegría en trabajar junto a su esposa e hijos que le apoyan en sus chacras. Su anhelo es comprar sus propios terrenos agrícolas, para que no sigan sembrando en tierras alquiladas, y de ese modo mejoren sus ingresos económicos, los que le permitan cubrir la educación de sus hijos que pronto necesitarán mayores recursos para que estudien. Rosalino acaba de juramentar como vocal de su banco comunal, donde ha hecho compromisos de cumplir sus funciones debidamente. Este es su 5to préstamo con MFP, y en todo este tiempo a pagado con mucha responsabilidad todas su cuotas sin caer en morosidad. El dinero que solicita es para la compra de fertilizantes e insecticidas para contrarrestar las plagas que asechan a sus plantas frutales.
texts.en:
Rosalino is 34 years old and has lived for 5 years with his partner with whom he has three children. At present they live in their own house. He and its wife have planted small gardens with coffee and a variety fruit plants. In some cases it will take 3 long years for the first harvest, in others it will be every 15 days. He is very pleased because this enterprise enables him to cover the cost of food and promote his family’s welfare, and it also makes him happy to be working with his wife and children who support him in tending their small gardens. He yearns to buy his own agricultural land so that they do not have to continue sowing rented land. This would improve their income, allowing him to provide an education for his children who will soon require greater resources to be able to study. Rosalino has just been sworn in as the director of the communal bank, where has made the commitment to comply with his duties and responsibilities. This is the 5th loan with MFP, and Rosalino has always been responsible for making all payments in a timely manner. The funds requested will be used to buy fertilizer and insecticide to combat plagues that attack his fruit-bearing plants.

Translated from Spanish by Lisette Artiga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and insecticide.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita P. is engaged in hog farming. She grows pigs to support her family's needs. She loves pigs very much, that is why she invests a lot of money in this endeavor. She is 54 years old and has 5 children. Aside from pigs, she also owns a 3-hectare farm. The income from her harvest is what she uses to feed and clothe her family. When they have plenty of harvest, they sell some of their rice to the traders in their village.

She is asking for a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy 2 sacks of feed for her pigs and to start a new business. She knows that her loan will help her develop her pig business. It will also help her to start a new business.

CEVI provides all their clients with credit assistance. They also give their clients training and insurance coverage to help them to develop their businesses and alleviate their poverty.

loans.use: To purchase two sacks of feed for the pigs and to start a new business.

loans.name: Simoneides

texts.en:
A 30-year-old, Simoneides "Simon" M. is from Tudela, Misamis Occidental. His father industriously cares for their photography business and he works for his father as an assistant.

The business is doing well. Simon personally took charge of their business when his father got sick. When he was challenged by financial difficulties, he has sought assistance from Paglaum. With his first loan, in 2008, he was able to purchase computer equipment and photography materials.

Now, Simon sees a good opportunity to venture into a new business for added income. He is requesting PHP 10,000 from Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative to buy salon supplies and accessories. He deeply wishes for a good return from their photography and salon businesses.

loans.use: To purchase additional salon supplies and equipment

loans.name: Salon Marlboro Group

texts.fr: Le salon de coiffure Marlboro est managé par Madame Bodien W. au quartier Boucotte de Ziguinchor. C'est un centre de formation aussi pour jeune fille à côté des prestations de services (mariages et autres coiffures de cérémonie). Madame W. et ses associées veulent renforcer par ce crédit leur salon et être plus attractive au regard de la concurrence.
texts.en:
Marlboro is a hair salon managed by Ms. Bodien W. in the Boucotte district of Ziguinchor. Aside from the range of services provided (hairstyles for marriages and for other special occasions), the salon is also a training center for girls. Ms. W. and her associates want to use this loan to bolster their salon and to be more attractive with regard to the competition.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Hair salon

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana is 40 years old and married with 7 children. She sells dried fish and other foodstuffs. She is requesting the loan amount of 100,000 Nigerian naira (or about $700 US) to purchase more foodstuffs and dried fish to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Dipa

texts.en:
Mrs. Dipa K. is a 36-year-old lady who lives in Sainbu-Bhaishapati, Lalitpur. Mrs. Dipa K. lives in a single family with her husband and two children. Her daughter is studying in grade 11 and her son is studying in grade 8. Mrs. Dipa is a center chief in her group. Being a center chief means she has taken responsibility for all her center members.

Mrs. Dipa and her husband, Mr. Ramesh K., opened their veterinary pharmacy four years ago. They sell different types of domestic-animal medicine in their shop. They both contribute equally in their shop because they don’t have any other jobs. Mrs. Dipa K. already has taken her first loan with Kiva and has cleared it. With the previous loan she was able to buy various medicines for her shop. Now Mrs. Dipa is requesting Rs 30000.00 to expand her business and buy more necessary medicines for her shop.

loans.use: To buy medicines for domestic animals

loans.name: Elyse

texts.fr:
A. Elyse est née vers 1961 à ABOMEY, Capitale historique du BENIN. Elyse est mariée à LOKO Daniel, un vitrier qui exerce sa profession à COTONOU, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Elyse et Daniel ont quatre 
enfants: deux filles et deux garçons qui sont tous au lycée. Elyse et sa famille vit à Suru-Léré un quartier populaire de la ville de Cotonou. C'est Daniel, le mari d'Elyse qui supporte les charges de la familles. Ainsi, Elyse réinvesti les revenus de son activité dans celle-ci pour mieux la développer. Elyse vend des beignets de haricot, de patate douce, de pomme de terre, de banane et d'igname frites depuis sept (7) ans à côté du lycée public de son quartier. Elyse a eu déjà quatre crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. L'activité d'Elyse a connu une évolution remarquable depuis son premier crédit. Pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus grandissante, Elyse sollicite un cinquième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Elyse was born around 1961 in ABOMEY, historic capital of Benin. Elyse is married to Loko Daniel, a glazier who works in Cotonou, economic capital of Benin. Elyse and Daniel have four children, two daughters and two sons who are all in high school.

Elyse and her family live in Suru-Léré, a working-class neighborhood of the city of Cotonou. It's Daniel, Elyse's husband, who supports the family. Thus, Elyse reinvests the income from her business so as to develop it better. Elyse has been selling fitters made of beans, sweet potatoes, potatoes, and bananas, and fried cocoyams for 7 years near the public high school in her neighborhood. Elyse has already had four loans from ALIDé, loans that she reimbursed correctly. Her business has undergone a remarkable evolution since her first loan. In order to better satisfy her ever-growing clientele, Elyse is requesting a fifth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of 1 sack of 100 kg of cocoyams, 50 kg of dried beans, 25 liters of peanut oil and firewood

loans.name: Martha

texts.es: Martha tiene 37 años, es casada. Como familia, junto a su esposo e hijos buscan salir adelante; por ello, uno de sus mayores logros ha sido la construcción de su casa propia. La habilidad que tiene para la elaboración de bocaditos le ha dado la oportunidad de iniciar hace 6 años su negocio de producción y venta de chocolates, lo cuales distribuye a las tiendas de su localidad y en las diversas reuniones sociales donde se lo solicitan. Estos contratos son más rentables, puesto que los pedidos son en grandes cantidades, de venta fija y ganancia rápida. A pesar de la tediosa preparación de los chocolates, Martha trata de disfrutarla junto a sus hijos, trabajando alegremente todos los días desde las 2 de la tarde hasta altas horas de la noche, tiempo que varía dependiendo del pedido, pues ha habido noches enteras sin dormir con tal de cumplir, pero su sacrificio tuvo su recompensa en las ganancias obtenidas. Para un futuro cercano, Martha quiere tener una fuente de soda donde pueda ofrecer variedades de bocaditos y chocolates. Este es su 13avo préstamo con Microfinanzas PRISMA, el tiempo de permanencia con su banco comunal ha sido de grandes posibilidades de desarrollo, ya que el trabajo en equipo que realiza con sus compañeras la ha ayudado a solucionar diversas circunstancias adversas. Los 2500 soles que solicita los invertirán en la compra de los ingredientes indispensables para la preparación de sus deliciosos bocaditos.
texts.en:
Martha is 37 years old and married. She seeks to succeed as a family with her husband and children; one of their greatest achievements was to build their own home. The skills she has to produce snacks gave her 6 years ago the opportunity to start her own chocolate production and sale business, and she distributes them at her local stores and in several social gatherings where she gets the orders. These sales are the most profitable, since the orders are in large quantities, fixed sales with a quick gain. Despite the tedious preparation of the chocolates, Martha tries to enjoy it next to her children, working happily every day from 2 in the afternoon until late at night. The time varies depending on the order, since there have been many nights when she didn't sleep just so she could fulfill an order, but her sacrifice has been rewarded with profits. In the near future Martha wants to have a soda fountain where she can offer snacks and chocolates. This is her 13th loan with Microfinanzas PRISMA. The long time she has been with the communal bank has been full of development possibilities, since the teamwork she does with her partners have helped her pull through several adverse situations. The 2500 soles she asks for will be invested in the purchase of ingredients that are necessary for the preparation of her delicious snacks.

Translated from Spanish by Esteban Riojas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients for her snacks and chocolates

loans.name: Darlene Del Socorro

texts.es: Doña Darlene es casada, de 52 años de edad, se desempeña como maestra de educacion primaria en el Centro Escolar Simon Bolivar de Acoyapa con 30 años de servicio, su esposo tiene un negocio de venta de carne y asume con los gastos del hogar.  Darlene tiene 4 hijos, 2 son casados, solo tiene a su cargo los 2 menores, uno de 15 años que estudia la secundaria y una de 18 años que estudia la universidad.  Esta solicitando su primer credito para construir una acera en su casa, pues con el invierno se hace un charco, ademas quiere construir un sumidero y terminar una tapia que ya tiene levantada una parte de la pared para brindarle mayor seguridad a su propiedad.   Sueña con poder seguir mejorando su casa pues es el patrimonio de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Darlene is 52 years old and married. She works as an elementary school teacher in the Simon Bolivar de Acoyapa school center with 30 years of service. Her husband has a business selling meat and takes care of the household expenses. Darlene has 4 children, 2 of whom are married, and thus she only has 2 in the house, a 15 year-old son that is in secondary school and a 19 year-old daughter that is in college. She is requesting her first loan to build a sidewalk for her house, since in winter the area becomes a puddle. In addition, she wants to build a drain and finish a fence so that her property is more secure. She dreams of improving her house since it's ultimately for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of sidewalk, drain and fence for her house

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a member of the Singolukele borrower group in Kola, Mororgoro. She is a 31-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of three children. Her children are aged 9, 5 and 2 years. She also cares for one other dependent.

Ten years ago Joyce started her own shop selling wheat, rice and sugar. She works fourteen hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 300,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Joyce’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more rice, wheat and sugar to sell. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, she hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice, wheat and sugar to sell

loans.name: Service Group

texts.en:
Bright is a 43-year-old father of four children who are schooling. He is very hard-working and resourceful to his family. He sells charcoal, firewood, and yams in his neighborhood.

Charcoal is very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all Ghanaian traditional homes. Bright obtains his supply of charcoal, firewood and yams from the surrounding villages in his community, where he lives, and retails them to his customers. With his two years' business and sales experience, he wants to use the loan to buy a bulk supply to increase his inventory. He hopes the loan will enable him to increase savings to pay for the children’s educational fees.

He is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Service’. He is the one sitting in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders and food vendors. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy bulk supplies of charcoal, firewood and yams

loans.name: Cate's Group

texts.en: S. Cate is the leader of her lending group in Mukono. She is a friendly, determined and hard working married lady with a salon business in Nakisunga town and it has been running for 18 years. She is a happy woman with good ways of handling her customers in addition to the experience she has and she is grateful because she is able to make some profits that in turn help to boost her business. Cate has dreams of expanding her business by starting another branch and this will enable her to give a much stronger helping hand in addition to her husband’s contribution. However, her main business challenge is having customers that do not want to pay on time for the services rendered and this affects her cash flow. She has 7 children and takes care of 1 orphan and the eldest of her children is at the University with a lot of school fees to pay. Cate needs a loan to be able to buy more hair oils, cosmetics and hair pieces for more stock.

loans.use: Buying more hair oiuls, cosmetics and hair pieces for the salon.

loans.name: Rainer

texts.en:
Rainer Z. is from the village of Sta.Cruz,Jimenez,Misamis Occidental. He is 35 years old. Rainer is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Rainer owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized "sari-sari" retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste etc.,in the local community. Rainer earns approximately 7,500.00 PHP a month.

In 2009, Rainer joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rainer is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rainer from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Chin

texts.en: Chin K. is 47 years old and resides in the Siem Reap province with her husband and two of her children. To earn a living, she has been growing and selling vegetables at the local market. She typically makes about $1 of profit every day. Her husband, pictured here, is a carpenter who is able to make around $5 each day. Chin is asking for a loan of $1,000 for her husband to be able to purchase wood and carpenter tools to expand his business.

loans.use: Buy wood and carpenter tools

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
Mary Grace A. is from the village of Purok 3 Inobulan, Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 46 years old. Mary Grace is widowed and has 1 adult-aged child. To make a living, Mary Grace owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store.Her main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Mary Grace has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mary Grace joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Grace is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Mary Grace from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory for her general store

loans.name: Merly

texts.en:
Merly P. is from the village of San Isidro Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 20 years old. Merly is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Merly owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Merly has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Merly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merly is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Merly from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth R. is from the village of Olingan. She is 44 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Elizabeth owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She is just starting this business. In 2006, Elizabeth joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. She will also use the loan to purchase construction materials for house repair. She plans to have a better shelter to live in. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies and to buy construction materials for house repair

loans.name: Maika

texts.en:
Maika B. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste in a market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of groundnuts for making paste to sell. Maika is 36 years old and is divorced. She has four children and they all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a beauty salon.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to stock more bags of groundnuts for making paste to sell.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
A used clothing dealer locally known as “okay-okay” and a "sari-sari" (variety) store operator is our featured entrepreneur of this story. She is Mrs. Rebecca T., 40 years of age, married and a resident of P1 San Apolinario, Tangub City. She is married to Rene T., who drives their motor cab for hire. Unfortunately, the couple are still not blessed with any children.

They started this "okay-okay" and sari-sari store business a year ago, and at this time they are earning an average net income of not less than 10,000 PHP. Her husband is also earning an average net income of 9,700 PHP a month from service as a motorcab driver. Rebecca joined PAGLAUM MPC just this year because she is very much interested in our products and services as we are one of the outstanding cooperatives in Northern Mindanao, awarded Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines during the search for COOP-LGU Partnership Award 2006.

With her good credit record based on her 1st loan history, she is given the privilege of accessing the amount of 50,000 PHP to add to her capital for her existing "okay-okay'" business. Their future plan in life is to have an additional outlet or display stand for their "okay-okay" business. The future income from this loan is for basic needs and savings for their family.

loans.use: Additional capital for her "okay-okay" business

loans.name: Olga Saturnina

texts.es:
La señora Olga es socia del Banco Comunal “Generación 2000” desD. hace 10 años, vive en el distrito D. Santa Rosa, provincia D. El Collao y departamento D. Puno, tiene 59 años D. edad, está casada y tiene 04 hijos. Ella estudió primaria completa,  se dedica a la compra y venta D. carne.

Olga nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, que fue D. S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, pudo comprar carne D. ovino.

Ahora ella solicitará un nuevo crédito  D. S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles con el cual podrá comprar carne D.: avino, alpaca, porcino y res.

Su sueño para el futuro es tener su emporio en Tacna y obtener su capital propio.

Lo que más le gusta D. su Banco Comunal es el ahorro y las facilidades para obtener un crédito.
texts.en:
Sra. Olga has been a member of the Generation 2000 Communal Bank for ten years. She lives in the District of Santa Rosa, El Collao Province, Department of Puno. She is 59 years old, married, and has four children. She has an elementary school education and operates a business buying and selling meat.

Olga says her first loan from Manuela Ramos was in the amount of 300 soles and used to buy sheep. Now she is requesting a new loan of 1000 soles to buy a variety of meats such as poultry, alpaca, pork, and beef. Her dream for the future is to open an emporium in Tacna and build up her own capital.

What she enjoys most about her Communal Bank are the savings account and the ease of obtaining credit.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a variety of meats

loans.name: Marieta

texts.en:
Marieta C. is from the village of D' Fernan Bonifacio. She is 41 years old. Marieta is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Marieta owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, some food for snacks, sugar, soap & toothpaste and other daily use products in the local community. Marieta has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Marieta joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marieta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from GDMPC. Marieta is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Marieta from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is 36 years old, widowed, and takes care of three children. She has been operating a retail shop in Naivasha town since 2006. She sells things like toothpaste, bar soaps, sugar, and rice.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to buy more goods to sell, including dry foodstuffs, maize, sugar, and rice.

In the future, she hopes to grow her business into a wholesale outlet.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell in her retail shop

loans.name: Feliza

texts.en:
A resident of Bolinsong, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental is our featured entrepreneur. She is Mrs. Feliza H., 39 years of age and married to Eddie H. who is a fisherman. They were blessed with 10 children. Two of the children are now working, three are school age and five are still infants. Her daughter is with her in the picture. The couple felt some hardships, especially in raising their 10 children. To help her husband, she decided to engage in business and opened up a sari-sari store in her house. For 10 years, she has been able to sustain the business. At this time she is earning an average net income of not less than P2,500 a month. This amount is so beneficial to their family, especially in meeting their daily needs. She undoubtedly joined the cooperative in 2010. As a newly recognized member, she is given the privilege to borrow P5,000 to add to her capital for her existing sari-sari store business. The future income from this loan will be used for their daily needs, tuition fees, loan repayments and savings for future use. She is hoping that someday all her children can graduate from college with the help of this business.

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders

loans.use: As additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Rwakirungura People's Association, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
K. Kenneth at the top right of the group photo also appears in the group photo and he is a 48-year-old married man and a banana plantation farmer in Nyabicence, Buyanja Sub County in Rukungiri district. He is a father to five children, plus one orphan who are all pursuing education.

Kenneth has been in the banana plantation business for the last eighteen years and attributes his longevity in the business to his good human relationship skills. He calculates that his business generates cash to the tune of 40,000 UGX per week and his business objective from the onset has always been to modernize his banana plantation so as to get more substantial value from it.

By his own account, one of the major challenges he has to grapple with is the unpredictable and adverse weather conditions which constantly destroy crops in that part of the country.

Kenneth hopes to educate all his children up to university level once he is able to elevate his business venture in the course of time. He envisages he will be able to buy more manure, pay his laborers on time and buy more farm equipment with this loan.

loans.use: To buy manure, pay his laborers, and buy more farm equipment

loans.name: 03.01.04 Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
Bay L. T. (4) is a 60 year-old femaL. living in the town of Hoang Hoa, Thanh Hoa.  Bay is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 03.01.04.

Bay is married and has 4 adult -aged children.  To making a living, Bay operates a family member's business venture in the food sector making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products such as fish and shrimp in the local community.  Bay has been engaged in this business for over 30 years and earns approximately 1.500.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2005, Bay joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Bay has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3.079.800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. The previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for saL..  She is now requesting a new loan of 5.000.000 VND which also will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for saL..  The loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Bay from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Bay plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  N. T. Dan (121) is a 51 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

2.  N. T. Nguyet (122) is a 27 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector running a general store.

3.  T. T. Tuyen (123) is a 25 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

4. L. T. Binh (124) is a 35 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector making & selling food.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Bay L. T. (4) là 60 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở  Hoang Hoa, Thanh Hoa.  Bay là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 03.01.04 Hoang Hoa (03.01.04 Hoang Hoa).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán hải sản như cá và tôm trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Bay thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 30 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Bay kiếm được khoảng 1.500.000 VND.  Vào 2005, Bay đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Bay đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3.079.800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các thành phần thô cần T.ết để chế tạo sản phẩm để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.000.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 6th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  N. T. Dan (121) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


2.  N. T. Nguyet (122) là 27 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hàng bách hóa.


3.  T. T. Tuyen (123) là 25 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


4.  L. T. Binh (124) là 35 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet M. lives in the village of Poblacion 4 Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old, married and has two school-aged children. Juliet makes a living by running a bakery where she makes items such as bread to sell to people in her area. She has been in this business for more than ten years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2009, Juliet joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC and is now applying for a new one for 20,000 PHP  She will use the additional revenue generated by her bakery to improve her family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is made up mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand her small bakery

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Madame Fatou  M. est une vendeuse de divers produits comme des pots de fleur, produits de lessive, des sacs, lampes, montres, chaussures … etc.  Elle est dans cette activité depuis 3 ans avec l’aide de son mari qui ne cesse de l’encourager. Agée de 36 ans, Madame Fatou M. est mère de 5 enfants et souhaitait un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour renforcer son business.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatou M. sells various products such as flower pots, laundry detergent, bags, lighting fixtures, watches, shoes, etc. She has been in business for the past three years and receives continued encouragement from her husband. Mrs. Fatou M. is 36 years old, the mother of five children, and is requesting a loan for 100,000 FCFA to strengthen her business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: resupply with various products

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe Sabougnouma sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans,  5 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles polygames à HAMDALLAYE un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Tous les prêts antérieurs se sont bien dénoués. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels que l’encens avec  Aoua Konté, le bois de chauffe, le gingembre,  les vêtements etc.
Aoua Konaté compte acheter avec son  prêt,  20kg de guenni + 10kg de magnon kisenin. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et effectue sa vente au  marché d’ HAMDALLAYE et en famille à une clientèle composée de femmes, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 11.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
NB : On note l’absence de Kadia Koné sur la photo, due à la maladie brusque de son enfant.
texts.en:
The seven members of this Sabougnouma group are essentially married women with an average age of 32 and on average 5 children, most of whom live in polygamous families in HAMDALLAYE, a neighborhood of the town of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). They are on their fifth collaboration with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with a view to satisfying their clientele. All their prior loans have been correctly resolved. This group of women sell various articles such as incense in the case of Aoua Konté, firewood, ginger, clothing, etc. Aoua Konaté intends to use her loan to buy 20 kg of "guenni" and 10 kg of "magnon kisenin" (ingredients for making incense). She buys her supplies in the big open-air market of the town of Sikasso and sells her products in the market of HAMDALLAYE and among her family members, to a clientele composed of women, for cash and often for credit. She expects to make an average monthly profit of 11,500 F CFA of which part will be used for family expenses and the rest reinvested in the business. Her ambition is to increase her sales and better satisfy her clientele. Note: Kadia Koné is not in the photo due to the sudden illness of her child.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy perfumes and other ingredients for making incense

loans.name: Victorina

texts.en: Victorina N. is from the village of Centro 2. She is 56 years old, is married, and has four adult children. Victorina owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over thirty years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Victorina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Victorina is requesting a new loan of 45,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her ninth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Maribel Zumel Group

texts.en:
Maribel Z. is from the village of Dolores, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old. Maribel is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Maribel Z. Group.

Maribel is married and has 3 school-aged children. She owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Maribel has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Maribel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maribel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC, which was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Maribel is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Maribel from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital

loans.name: John Mhar

texts.en:
John Mhar A. is from the village of Salay, Misamis Oriental. He is 26 years old. John Mhar is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, John Mhar owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food & daily use products and also selling vegetables and fruits in the local community, managed by his wife. John Mhar has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, John Mhar joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. John Mhar has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. John Mhar is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by John Mhar from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.es: Zenaida tiene 41 años, vive con su  esposo y sus 5 hijos en su casa propia. Desde hace 12 años viene desempeñando sus labores en su fábrica de ladrillos a lado de su esposo que trabajan sin descanso para producir ladrillos  de calidad y en cantidades. Su trabajo es muy duro ya que requiere de mucho esfuerzo físico, su pareja se levanta cada madrugada para  calentar el horno y por las mañanas Zenaida  ayuda en la preparación de la  masa de arcilla para darle forma y serán depositadas luego en los moldes de ladrillo y dejarlas secar en el sol  por  un día entero, y al estar secos se depositan en el horno  para coserse  hasta por el lapso de 24 horas. Afirma que su trabajo es muy sacrificado pero a la vez muy rentable en sus ganancias es por eso que desea tener una fábrica más amplia de ladrillos. Es su catorceavo crédito con MFP, esta muy contenta de saber que tiene un apoyo financiero ya que siempre ha demostrado  ser responsable en sus pagos, además  le agrada ser parte de su grupo comunal porque  todos sus integrantes son personas responsables y muy solidarias, agradece aquellas personas que serán gestoras del préstamo que solicita ya que le será  muy útil en el progreso de su negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, utilizará en la compra de materiales necesarios para la fabricación de ladrillos como arena fina, aserrín y cal.
texts.en:
Zenaida, 41, lives with her husband and their five children in their own home. For the past 12 years she has been working alongside her husband in the brick factory they own. They work tirelessly to produce large quantities of quality bricks. It is hard work because it requires much physical effort. Her partner gets up at dawn to heat the oven and in the morning Zenaida helps with the preparation of the clay to shape it. Later it is put in the brick moulds, which are left out to dry in the sun for a whole day. Once dry, the bricks are baked for 24 hours in the oven. She says it is very demanding work but also very profitable, and that is why she wants to have a larger brick factory. This is her loan number fourteen with MFP. She is very happy to have financial backing as she has always proven to be very responsible with her payments. She also enjoys being part of the loan group because all members are responsible and very supportive. She thanks those individuals managing the loan she is requesting as it will be very useful in the development of her business. With the requested loan she will buy the necessary materials for brick manufacture, such as fine sand, sawdust and lime.

Translated from Spanish by Alba Sort , Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials for brick manufacture.

loans.name: Ernesto

texts.es: El Sr. Ernesto  vive en el Barrio Brígida  y Cuarto Anillo Zona Norte de la Ciudad de Santa Cruz, el es mecánico tiene su propio taller en su domicilio, el se dedica a la mecánica desde hace cuatro años junto con su hermano y tiene un ayudante, el destino del préstamo es para terminar de cancelar la ultima cuota de la compra de un vehículo que le ayuda en su taller y para comprar herramientas, el Señor Ernesto esta aumentando su clientela y tiene como meta agrandar su taller para ofrecer un mejor servicio y para eso se esta esforzando mucho ya que el es muy trabajador y responsable, esta muy agradecido con Emprender  y Kiva por la confianza brindad en la otorgación del credito.
texts.en:
Ernesto lives in the Brígada y Cuarto Anillo neighborhool in the northern area of the city of Santa Cruz. He is a mechanic, and he has his own shop at his house. He has been working as a mechanic for four years. He works with his brother, and they have a helper. The loan is to make the last payment on a vehicle purchase, which helps him in his shop, and to buy tools. Ernesto is getting more customers, and his goal is to expand his shop in order to provide better service. He is putting forth a lot of effort to do so, and he is very hard-working and responsible. He is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the trust shown by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tools

loans.name: Song Va's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Song Va P., 31 years old, is the bank president selected by the thirteen members of this village bank loA. located in Boeng Krum Leu village, Kandal province. The members of this loA. will use the money to buy supplies, equipment and other items to support their different purposes.

Mrs. Song Va P. is a beauticiA. working from her home and also a singer for Khmer traditional weddings. She is able to earn a small income to support her family. She is requesting a loA. to buy beauticiA. supplies to support her business. Mrs. Song Va P. is a widow with four children; three attend the local public school and the fourth is 5 years old and not in school yet.

loans.use: To buy supplies to support her business

loans.name: Damacia

texts.es:
La Sra. Damacia  posee una farmacia en su domicilio, ella hace 10 diez años que se dedica a este rubro , ya que anteriormente trabajaba como vendedora en una farmacia  y D. alli  , se propuso en abrir su propia faramacia y eso lo logro con mucho esfuerzo y estudios realizados, ella es casada con 3  hijos  en edad escolar.
Con un poco D. su ahorro pudo montar su negocio y se   independizo.
Ella necesita D. este crédito para la compra D. mas mercaderia ya que tiene varios pedidos. En el futuro  desea abrir  mas locales.
texts.en:
Damacia runs a pharmacy in her house, an activity she has been running for 10 years. As she previously worked as a shop assistant in a pharmacy, she thought about opening one of her own, something she achieved with great effort and by studying hard. She is married and has three children of school age. With some of her saving s she was able to start her activity and so to get economic independence. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy more products, as she receives many requests. In the future she wishes to have a bigger shop.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy medicines to sell.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a married man with two children who are in school.  He makes soap dishes, necklaces, bangles, earrings, spoons and dishes. He is able to make these products because he is talented artistically.  He has been in the business for two years and he has five employees. 

Previously, he was farming to earn his daily bread.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to save his money.  He hopes to buy a piece of land in the future, and he dreams of owning a big curio shop some day.  He has requested a loan of 50,000 KES to add to his stock of raw materials for making curios.

loans.use: To add to his stock of raw materials for making curios

loans.name: Zinabala  Nassuti Development Group-Mukono

texts.en: Janiffer N., a happily married mother of 4, has been selling fish for the last 4 years in Nasuti-Mukono. Hard work and dedication lie at the root of her continuing track record of success. Accruing profits from this business has, to a certain magnitude, enabled her to keep her head above the water. In a week, her profits equate to 40,000 shillings and she is looking forward to using this loan money to buy more fish stock for resale. With more sales profits, she reckons she will be able to elevate the welfare status of her family even further.

loans.use: The purchase of more fish for resale

loans.name: Mirasol

texts.en:
Mirasol A. is a 59-year-old mother who cares for her three children. She is married to, Amador, a fisherman. To help to support her husband, she started her own fishing business. 

She dreams to get away from poverty. In 2007 she came across the idea of joining ASHI(Ahon Sa Hirap Inc.), which means “To Rise Up from Poverty”, and KIVA partner in the Philippines. Since her membership in the institution she has shown good performance in her credit rating (basis of loans) in order to get bigger capital for her business.

Now on her sixth loan, she has applied for a new loan amounting to PHP 30,000.00 to buy new “Skylab” (fish trap). She believes that one additional fish trap will catch more fish to gain better output. 

In the future, Mirasol hopes to establish a stall in the market where she can sell her fish. She also wants to be able to save for her children's education and to build a comfortable house for living and a happy family to live with.

loans.use: To buy new "skylab" (fish trap).

loans.name: Chuluunbat

texts.en:
Chuluunbat M. is 48 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His oldest daughter is a university student in Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia, and his youngest daughter attends a local secondary school. 

Chuluunbat is a carpenter and produces a variety of home furnishings according to his customers' orders. He started his wood products production business in 1998 after working as a carpenter in a local company for 10 years. His wife, Ulziijargal, manages a consumer goods and clothing items trade business in their town. His wife has been engaged this business since 2002, selling a variety of consumer goods and clothes in the local market. 

Their business is located in the popular spot of the market which attracts many customers. Chuluunbat says, "I work hard to improve and expand our businesses till my two daughters grow up and become good people with high educational background who can support us back." 

He is requesting a 1,300,000 MNT loan to purchase more clothes and consumer goods to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and consumer goods

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.en:
Eduardo F. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is married and has 5 children. Eduardo is involved in farming and raising pigs. He owns and tills  farmland where he plants rice. His wife helps him sell his harvest at the market. Eduardo also grows pigs for fattening and sale. He says pork meat sells well in his town, especially during special occasions. 

Eduardo needs additional capital to invest in his farm and pigs. He is requesting a loan of Php 10,000 which he will use to purchase feed and farm fertilizers.  He plans to use the additional revenue generated by the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase feed and fertilizers

loans.name: Sochea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sochea L. (pictured with her son) is 31 years old and her husband, Mr. Kry Yin, is 38 years old. They live along National Road Number Six about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1995 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Mr. Kry Yin is a fisherman. 

Sochea sells fish that her husband catches in her village. She is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase fishing materials for her husband’s business and to buy a motorcycle for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase fishing materials and a motorcycle

loans.name: Nana

texts.en: Nana A. is married and has one child. She sells cocoyam, plantain and charcoal in Takoradi. Her husband is a wood seller.  Nana assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  Nana will use the loan to buy more foodstuffs to supply her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Nana plans to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Oyun

texts.en:
Oyun N. is a 68-year-old woman who lives with her daughter, son-in-law and two grandchildren in Han-Uul district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a house with a fence. Her daughter works as a glass washer for the APU Company, while her son-in-law is a driver at the local police department. Her grandchildren both are in kindergarten. 

Oyun operates a grocery trading business in the city. She started her business in 1998 in a small shop and has since built a stable operation. For the future, she plans to expand her business and open her own grocery store. Oyun is requesting  a 1000000 MNT loan to purchase more products in order to expand her product line for her small food shop.

loans.use: To purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Isabel

texts.es:
Isabel, D. 36 años, convive con su esposo y padre D. su hijo Francisco D. 1 año,  vive en su casa heredada que ahora es propia. Tras el fallecimiento D. su padre; Isabel  procedió con el negocio D. L. cerrajería junto a su madre Isabel, pero como le aquejaba una enfermedad, tuvo que dejar L. cerrajería por un tiempo  hasta que se recupere. 

Hoy el local donD. realiza dicha actividad lo tiene alquilado, para no perder sus clientes que constantemente requerían D. sus servicios. ElL. sabe y conoce mucho D. este negocio y D. las buenas ganancias que capta. Por esta razón más adelante piensa trabajar con otras personas en su taller y D. ese modo forjarse un futuro más promisorio para su familia. Pero, mientras tanto, está hacendosa mujer a decidido emprender un  negocio D. venta D. ropa  casual, para ofrecerlos a sus familiares, amigas y vecinas D. su barrio, ya que es una mujer que está acostumbrada a trabajar.  

Es el 5to crédito con MFP, y se compromete en ser responsable con el pago D. sus cuotas, pues no quiere ser un mal cliente, porque desea seguir contando con posteriores ayudas. D. obtener el crédito que solicita, comprará prendas D. vestir para atender los pedidos que ya tiene.
texts.en:
36 year-old Isabel lives with her husband and 1 year-old son Francisco.  She lives in a house which she inherited and is now hers.  Following the death of her father, Isabel kept his locksmith's business running, together with her mother.  However, she suffered an illness and therefore had to leave the locksmith's for a while until she recovered.

Today, the premises where she runs her business are rented so that she doesn't lose her customers who constantly need her services.  She knows a lot about this business and the good profits that it makes.  For this reason, in the future she is thinking of employing more people in her workshop so that she can forge a more promising future for her family.  In the meantime, this hard-working woman has decided to set up a business selling casual clothes to her family members, friends and neighbors since she is a woman who is accustomed to working.

This is Isabel's 5th loan with MFP and she pledges to be responsible in making her repayments.  She doesn't want to be a bad client because she would like to continue being able to rely on future help.  She will use her loan to buy clothes so that she can fill some orders that she already has.

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Djiguitougou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djiguitougou est composé de quatre femmes mariées (2 monogames et 2 polygames) ayant en moyenne 44 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le quartier Hamdallaye de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de leurs activités de petit commerce dans le marché Château de Ségou. Les membres du groupe font l’achat et la vente de pagnes wax, d’habits pour enfants et de poisson fumé. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce et de se ravitailler au comptant, les membres du groupe ont adhéré au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 11ème prêt solidaire.
Madame Hawa  Kané compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 200 kg de poissons fumés. Elle est ravitaillée en poisson en gros et à domicile par des fournisseurs (des femmes de pêcheurs de Markala). La revente se fait en détail, au comptant et à crédit à domicile et au marché Château à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 
Madame Hawa  Kané espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité, prendre en charge certains besoins du foyer et les soins de santé et la scolarisation des enfants. 
Elle ambitionne acheter un lot à usage d’habitation dans ce partenariat avec Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
The Djiguitougou group is made up of four married women (two monogamous and two polygamous) who average 44 years of age with three children each. They all live in the Hamdallaye district of Ségou (Mali's fourth administrative region) and got to know each other through relatives and their small business activities in Ségou's Château market. The members of the group buy and sell "pagnes wax" (highly decorative and colourful West African pieces of fabric), children's clothing and smoked fish. 

With the aim of increasing their working capital and getting fresh supplies for cash, the members of the group joined Soro Yiriwaso's loan program and they are now on their eleventh group loan. 

Mrs. Hawa Kané is planning to use her loan to buy 200kg of smoked fish. She gets her supplies of fish wholesale and at home from suppliers (fishermen's wives from Markala). She resells them on a retail basis, for cash and on credit, at home and at the Château market to a customer base made up principally of women. 

Mrs. Kané is hoping to make an average monthly profit of 50,000FCFA with this loan, and she will use this profit to reinvest in her business and to cover certain household needs as well as her children's health and schooling expenses. Her ambition is to buy, in collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso, a piece of land to live on.

loans.use: To purchase smoked fish

loans.name: Sum

texts.en: Sum S., 34, resides with her family in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. S. raises pigs to sell, earning an income of 2 USD per day. Her husband sells ice-cream, earning an income of 3 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend 66 USD on food and 60 USD on other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of 700 USD to purchase a new motorbike for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her family's use.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina M. is divorced and has one child. She has been selling wax prints for clothing for 15 years in Effiakuma Estate, near Takoradi. 

As the sole breadwinner, Amina wants to increase her income by expanding her business. She plans to use her loan to purchase additional prints for sale. She intends to save up the additional profits she earns so she can build a shop.

loans.use: To purchase additional prints for sale

loans.name: María Tarcila

texts.es:
María tiene 55 años de edad, es casada y reside junto a su familia en el caserío San Pablo  que esta a 8km de la localidad de Tambogrande, un distrito agrícola que se encuentra situado en la región Piura, a más de cuatro horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo, capital de la región Lambayeque.

María se dedica a la crianza y venta de ovejas, las cuales cría en un corral cercado en un terreno cerca a su domicilio, cuando estos ya han alcanzado un buen nivel de desarrollo los ofrece en venta al público en general y a los negociantes que suelen visitar la zona. Esta actividad la realiza desde hace más de 20 años por ello conoce a la perfección este rubro, contando con clientela fidelizada. Con los ingresos que percibe de esta actividad ayuda  a su esposo para sacar adelante a su familia.

María desea ampliar su negocio comprando más animales y alimento balanceado de modo que pueda aumentar sus ventas y mejorar su calidad de vida. Por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles.
texts.en:
María is 55 years old, married, and lives together with her family in the village of San Pablo, 8km from the town of Tambogrande.  This is an agricultural district which is located in Piura region, more than four hours from the city of Chiclayo, capital of Lambayeque region.

María raises and sells sheep.  She raises them in an enclosed pen on a plot of land near her home.  When they have reached a good level of development she offers them for sale to the general public and to the traders who visit her area.  María has been in this business for more than 20 years and therefore knows this line of work to perfection and has a loyal customer base.  She uses the income that she makes in her business to help her husband get their family ahead in life.

María would like to expand her business, buying more animals and balanced feed, so that she can increase her sales and improve her quality of life.  For this reason, she is requesting a loan for 1,500 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: to buy animals and balanced feed

loans.name: Bayarjavhlan

texts.en:
Bayarjavhlan, 25, is married and lives with her husband and son in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. They  live in a house provided by her husband's employer for a few years. Her husband works for a local flight company. 

Bayarjavhlan began selling clothes in 2010. She sells clothing out of a rented stall and her current inventory is valued at about 800,000 MNT. She wants to expand her business and increase her working capital in order to save money to buy an apartment. She is a hardworking and active person who says, "I want to expand my business further and have my own stall or a store and save money to buy an apartment." She is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
This is Marivic O., 43. She is a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Flaviano O., a maintenance man. She is the mother of three children, one of whom is already working and the other two are still studying — one in college and one in high school. By the grace of God, Marivic has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to send her youngest to college. This is the dream for most Filipino parents like Marivic, as she herself has been a college graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Marivic does a little sideline work besides her handwoven bags and scapulars business: she has a trading business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers, then sells items piecemeal with a small profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing, and other items. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options that are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Marivic dreams to be able to give her all her children a high-quality education through all her hard work on her business. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen has been living in Sahiwal for the past 12 years with her family in a two-room brick house. Sahiwal is a small city in Pakistan known for its agriculture. She is 39 years old and has given birth to two sons and two daughters. Her eldest son works with his father in his Punjabi food restaurant business. Yasmeen’s husband whose name is J. H. operates his restaurant in the market where he sells different varieties of Punjabi food at cheap rates. The taste is good and that’s why he attracts a good number of customers every day.
